G.C. = Global Chinese (å…¨çƒè¯äºº)

  • The Reporter

According to IORGâ€™s database, the most popular topics of last week were â€œrestriction micro-relaxationâ€ (colloquially â€œå¾®è§£å°â€, to partially relax restrictions) and â€œvaccination registration.â€

At 18:43 July 9th, a LINE message related to South Koreaâ€™s relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions appeared on Cofacts, containing false information that â€œalmost 50% of the Korean population has received the first dose of vaccine,â€ and â€œ30% are fully vaccinated.â€

The next day, July 10th, Taipei City Mayor Ko Wen-je made a similar remark in a press conference by saying that â€œKoreaâ€™s first-dose coverage is more or less complete, and second-dose coverage is almost 30%.â€ Yet according to statistics provided by Our World in Data, University of Oxford, South Koreaâ€™s first-dose coverage is approximately 30.67% by July 13th. Koâ€™s remarks were false.

According to IORGâ€™s database, LINE messages regarding Koreaâ€™s first-dose coverage appeared at least 50 times last week in as many as 21 unique variations, which can be grouped into 4 categories: Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and Delta. Common features among these categories are the false information that â€œKoreaâ€™s first-dose vaccination is almost complete,â€ â€œsecond-dose at almost 30%,â€ and â€œrestriction micro-relaxation for 3 days.â€ Also, only messages of the Delta category corrected a typo appearing in all other 3 categories. Messages with â€œcareful editsâ€ were also found, including the addition of links to legitimate news reports, confirmed case numbers of Asian countries, or enhancements of typography. Based on the data we collect, IORG is able to observe and categorize differences among these messages, yet the motivation behind still awaits further research.

In the 2nd Weekly, IORG shared a narrative of Chinese propaganda during the pandemic: â€œTaiwanese going to China to get vaccinated.â€ Following this thread, we have found â€œTaiwanese going to Chinese embassies to get vaccinatedâ€ in this Weekly. This narrative has appeared in a video of YouTube channel â€œHistoryBroâ€ (é«˜é›„æ­·å²å“¥) and was picked up and disseminated by Chinese state media Huanqiu Net (ç¯çƒç½‘), PRCâ€™s Taiwan Affairs Office, and other Chinese media outlets. IORG considers this shift in narrative a reflection of the gradual increase in the number of vaccines available within Taiwan, and the possible decrease of attractiveness in â€œgoing to China to get vaccinated.â€ Accordingly, China shifts its attention to the overseas Taiwanese unprotected by domestic vaccine supply, and uses its â€œSpring Sproutâ€ (æ˜¥è‹—) vaccination program to highlight its grand demeanor of â€œhelping Chinese people around the world.â€ However, according to IORGâ€™s database, there were only 6 posts from Mandarin Facebook pages sharing this narrative.

On July 5th, Japanâ€™s Deputy Prime Minister said the country needed to defend Taiwan with the U.S. if the island was invaded by China. IORG found multiple occurrences of clustered posting while observing CCP reactions and the dissemination of related narratives.

According to our database, 9 Facebook pages, with names starting with â€œGlobal Chineseâ€ (å…¨çƒè¯äºº), were involved in 13 clustered posting events, sharing articles from â€œqiqiâ€ content farms (domain name containing â€œqiqiâ€ and names containing â€œçªçªâ€ or â€œç¦ç¦â€). The Reporter in 2019 has reported that content farms and Facebook pages with names containing â€œQi-qiâ€ (çªçª) or â€œGlobal Chineseâ€ (å…¨çƒè¯äºº) belonged to the same operation. While the names are similar to those uncovered by IORG in this Weekly, further investigations are required to confirm their connections. Clustered posting is a behavioral pattern regardless of content. IORG will continue to study the relationship between clustered posting and information manipulation.

Finally, IORG again cautions suspicious narratives related to vaccines. Messages accusing AZ vaccines from Japan are not â€œcertifiedâ€ by WHO, problematic, or ill-intentioned continue to appear, as well as false claims that the Japanese AZ vaccines use ingredients from India. After the signing of contracts between Chinese vaccine manufacturers and COVAX, IORG expects narratives regarding â€œDPPâ€™s blocking of Chinese vaccines from COVAXâ€ to appear. Readers should stay alert.

Full version of this Dokidoki Alert Weekly is available in Taiwanese Mandarin. Please visit https://iorg.tw/da/6 for moreâ€¦
